div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, FRIDAY, APRIL 20, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Scakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor,(for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: THE OLYMPIC GAMES
div.p: On Sunday next the revived Olympic Garnet will for the second time be held at Athens, and athletes and spectators from every part of the world will be assembled is the marble- covered station to celebrate the renewal of a festival which takes us back to the very dawn of history. As a writer in the “Morning Post” says, no one knows when exactly the Olympic Games were started or who first suggested them. Candidates for the Ireland-Scholarship, reading Pindar with wet towels round their heads and strong tea at their elbows, are aware that the most sporting of Greek poets ascribed their origin to Hercoles, in comme moration of his victory over King Augeas of Blis— the monarah whose stabler would have so greatly seandalised the modern sanitary inspector. The usually received legend makes Pelops the first winner in the games, and the fair Hippodameia the prize of the first contest. Then we are told how phitos of Blis, at a time of great distress and distension, revived the Olympic festival at the bidding of the Dolphin Oracle, in the Ninth Century, and how, at last, in 776 bc., the catalogae of Olympic victors began with the name of Coiceboa, the local champion. As was natural, the Games, held every fourth year, were at first merely a local event; communication between the various States of Greeoe was slow, there was a great deal of jealousy between them, and it was only after a considerable lapse of time that other Peloponnesians, and then Athenians and Boeotians, competed for the garland of wild olive. At last the Olympic Games become the bond of caion between the scattered members of the whole Greek race, j net as we federate oar Empire at Lord’s or Henley,- and the Olympiad* became the national calendar, just as old racing men date events from the year of Hermit’s Derby, and old rowing-m^n calculate time by the dead-heat in the ’Varsity Boat Race. Gradually, as was natural, the programme was expanded. Originally the sports consisted exclusively of exercise* testing the endurance and strength of the combatants and thus demonstrating tetir fitness for war; for such contests, conducted on a small scale, a single day was sufficient Then the Game* were revolutionised by the introduction of the four- horse chariot race, an innovation which made 'hem mainly spectacular and which encouraged display. Pindar dewribes how on one occasion no less than forty chariots took part in one of these races, and the estate Athenian statesman, anxions to win popularity with the masses, found it an excellant investment to enter seven chariots at 0 umpia, just as British Prime Ministers have attained notoriety among those who take little interest in politics by winning the Dei by. The traveller Paotanias, in the Second Century of oar era, enumerates no less than 2 different items in the programme which he porehaeod at Olympia, among them the 200 yards flat nee, the doable coarse twice that distance, the long race, horse-races, (nestling and boxing combined in the pankration, and the famous pentathlon, which Simonides has so neatly described in a pentameter as consisting of “leaping, running, throwing the quoit, hurliog the javelin, and wrestling.'' This typically Hellenic erent has been incloded in the programme of the forthcoming contests at Athens. For all these 24 items five day* were not too long; twice that number will be devoted to the revived Olympic Games. We British can understand better than anyone else the extraordinary worship oi athleticism which these sports developed in ancient Greece. When Thucydides says that g popular general was mobbed and stared et by an admiring crowd "as if he were an athlete,” or when Akibiades pats his achievements in the chariot race as the first and foremost of his lervioes to his country, we think of W. G. Grace and C. B, Fry, of votes at elections polled by candidates who had been famous football players, of luorative posts at schools assigned to ‘Blues” whose bowling was better than their mathematic*. Gradually in Greece, as with ne, professionalism laid its hand upon sport; it was not a bad way of earning a living to win a race and to obtain the right to have free meal* in the Pry tension—a privilege now to be bestowed upon the children in our elementary sohools. Euripides, the Kipling of his tissue, said that “of all the evil* of Greece the athlete was the worst another writer observed that Olympic winners did not make the best soldiers. Still, the festival dragged on for centaries patronised by Roman Emperors like Nero, who inserted a new event in the Olympic programme in order to show off his musical gifts, till at last the bigoted Theodosias, with all the seal of h Spaniard, stamped out every vestige of Paganism, the Olympic Games among" them. They had long ceased to be a purely Hellenic festival, for the last recorded winner was an Armenian

div.head: (CYPRUS.) THE OLYMPUS HOTEL.
div.p: On Mount Troodos : 6,000 feet above sea level. Perfect climate. Magnificent scenery. Season June to October. For inclusive terms and information apply to the Manager, Cyprus Hotel Company, Limassol, Cyprus.

div.head: SAN FRANCISCO'S DOOM
div.p: Gazette's Special Service )
London, Friday.

Latest cables from America state that tot .1 detraction by fire appears to be the rapidly approaching doom of San Francisco. As there is no water available explosives are used for the purpose of preventing the fires increasing. It is estimated that 400,000 people are homeless and that 5,00 t lives have been lost, while the damage is pat down at £ 60,0 00.000 a large proportion of which will probably fall on the British insurance offices.
Los Angelos has also been visited by a shock The disturbances were severe, creating terrible panic.
Bawley, an unimportant town 120 miles south of Los Angelos, is described as having been wiped out of existence

div.head: BRITISH GARRSION IN EGYPT
div.p: TO BE INCREASED.
A Reuter’s telegram from London of to day's date states that it has been decided to increase the British garrison in Egypt.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: Cattle Plague.
Bovine typhus now exists in the Belbeis district.
Quarantine.
Quarantine restrictions as against plague are now applied in Egyptian ports to arrivals from Moulmein.
The Brindisi Mail.
The mail for Europe, via Port Said and Brindisi, will close at the G. P. 0 , Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m. on Sunday.
Telegrams for ’Frisco.
We are informed by the Eastern Telegraph Company that, owing to the earthquake, telegrams for San Francisco can only he accepted at senders’ risk.
Business Announcement
The ■-dimeters of the British Dominions Marine- Insurance Co., Ltd., have appointed Mwi. F. W. Coining & Co. their general agents and attorneys for Egypt.
Olympic Games-
The amount of persons who are leaving or have left Alexandria for the Olympic Games is very great. This afternoon the Khedivial Company’s Ismailia leaves absolutely fall.
French v. English.
At the last examination for junior clerks on probation for the Egyptian Railway Administration, out of forty candidates, thirty- six elected to be examined in English in lien of French.
A Cairo Nuisance.

A Cairo correspondent writes Why cannot the Tanzim Department, or whatever service it be that controls the watering carts of Cairo, have some regard for the slumbers of the overworked and underpaid officials, who live in the Ismailia quarter 6r the Capita! 1 At 8 o'clock in the morning the watering-carts frequently come about the streets and make a terrific noise at that early hour. Sleep is impossible.
Black Diamond Minstrels.

The final rehears kl of the Black Diamond Minstrel troupe takes place to night and the performance at the Ziznia Theatre to-morrow promised to be a huge success The whole “house” has practically been sold already, and those desirous of witnessing a first-class entertainment should not fail to book the few remaining seats while there is yet time. The proceeds of the performance are to go, partly, to the Alexandria Swimming Club and, partly, to the Philoptochos Benevolent Society.
Insurance Companies in Egypt

As will be seen by a circular published on page 4 of to-day's issue, the Union Assurance Society of London have decided to open a branch office in this country which will no doubt be of advantage to their clients and friends. The Union Assurance 8ooiety is one of the oldest insurance companies in existence, having been established in A. D. 1714, and is the first British fire insurance office to open a branch office in Egypt- Their branch manager, Mr. F. Franghia, has for many years specially occupied himself with insurance holiness, and has had long experience in this business.
Carriage Mishap.

Towards eight o’clock lest evening the horses of a private carriage bolted down Rotetta street and after careering madly for some distance overturned the vehicle, which was completely wrecked. The carriage was occupied by a lady, who, however, escaped any personal injury ; the driver was thrown from his seat and hurt his leg. Mr. Rowden, the riding master, was amongst the first on the scene, and did yeoman service in freeing the maddened animals from the wreakage in which they were entangled. The police were also promptly upon the spot, and under the direction of Mr Rowden, whose pluck deserves a word of praise, soon restored order. We must also congratulate the lady, who showed remarkable nerve under very trying circumstances.

div.head: PRINCE OF WALES AND ALEXANDRIA
REGRETS VISIT WAS IMPOSSIBLE
DONATION TO VICTORIA COLLEGE
div.p: We are requested by H.U. Consol-General in Alexandria to publish the following letter received from Sir Arthur Bigge, the private secretary to H.R.H. the Prince of Wales: — Cairo, 4th April, 1905.

Dear Mr. Gould,—I am directed by the Prince of Wales to tell you how sorry the Princess and he are that it has not been possible for them to visit Alexandria daring their short stay in Egypt. But Their Royal Highnesses fully appreciate the kindness of the British community in wishing to welcome them to that city.
The Prince and Princess would have been especially interested to see the Victoria College, which memorial to our late beloved Queen they are glad to hear is doing such good work.
The Prince of Wales desires me to forward the enclosed £20 as a donation from him to that Institution.—Believe me Dear Mr. Goold, years very faithfully, (Sgd.) Arthur Biooe.
We understand that it is proposed to devote the donation of the Prince to the purchase of a portrait of Q teen Victoria to be placed in the hall of the college.
The Khedive attended prayers to-day at Montazah Mosque.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: At its last meeting the Council of Ministers approved the definite appointment of Captain Flower as Director-General of the Gbizeh Zoological Gardens. It also approved a credit of L.B. 950 for certain urgent repairs in the Ministry of Finance.

div.head: MOSLEM BENEVOLENT SOCIETY.
div.p: T. E. Hassan Pasha Assem and Adly Pasha Yaghen, vice presidents of the Cairo Moslem Benevolent Society, called on Tuesday on H.H. Prince Haseein Pasha Kamel, accompanied by Abdel Halim Pasha Assem, Hassan Pasha Abd el Razzak, Hussein Pasha Sionfi, and Derwish Bey 8idi Ahmed, to present the Prince with a letter formally appointing him president of the society in the letter the board of the society made some most complimentary references to the new president and remarked that no other appointment could have been as popular.

In a brief speech of thanks H.H. Prince Hussein Kamel thanked his visitors for their kind words and declared that he accepted the hononr with the greater pleasure since H.H. the Khedive deigned to approve of his nomination by the post. In all that concerned charity he could promise his most energetic aid.
THE TABAH DISPUTE.
It is stated that Roshdi Pacha, who is in command of the Akaba garrison, has asked to be supplied with provisions for the Turkish troops for twelve months.
THE BAHR-EL-GHAZAL.
In the House of Commons on Wednesday week, Sir G. Parker asked the Secretary for Foreign Affairs whether a settlement of the Bahr-el-Qhazal question had been made with the Congo Government.

Sir K Grey : A final settlement has not been come to, but a modus vivendi his been arranged pending negotiations for a definite settlement, which will begin after Easter. In the meantime the arrangement now come to will prevent any difficulty arising with the Congo State troops or any confusion as to the administration of the frontier.

Sir G. Parker : Are the Congolese troops now in occupation of Sudanese territory, as has been the case for some time past 1 • Sir E. Grey : The modus vivendi is roughly this: That any posts occupied by Congo State forces subsequent to a certain date— about a year ago—will be withdrawn. Those which were there previous to that date will remain for the present, but the administration of the disputed territory will be Sudanese.
NORTH EGYPT LAND COMPANY.

Mr. Harry Gulliver, secretary of the above company, writes to us as follows :—I beg to inform you that my company has been officially advised by Maltre Carton de Wiart, it* legal representative in Egypt, that the estate which it was formed to acquire has now been transferred to this company, and that we have a perfect title to the same. Will you please make this announcement in your next issue and also state that my board will now take immediate steps for the development of their property.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner Khephren arrived here yesterday afternoon from Constantinople.
The Moss liner Seti arrived at Liverpool yesterday afternoon.
The Canard S.S. Veria arrived at Liverpool yesterday afternoon.

div.head: THE DEWEY AT PORTSAID
MANUEVRES ON ARRIVAL
div.p: (From our Correspondent).
Port Said, Thursday.

As I informed yon in my wire of this morning, the famous floating dock Dewey has at last arrived here, after a long and anxious voyage from the States. Up to the time of writing, the work of mooring still goes on. which effectually precludes all chances of conversation with members of her crew, so that I am able to send yon but little information about her voyage and adventures.

About 2 p.m. yesterday the huge warehouse like structure, surrounded by a cloud of smoke emitted by the three cruisers, and at tended by her two tug boats, hove in sight, and steam was immediately raised on the Canal Company's tags, which were sent out to meet the little fleet. Soon after 5 p.m. the convoy was outside the channel entrance, but it was thought that the work of mooring would not be completed before dark and consequently the whole fleet, dock and all, anchored to the east of the outer buoys for the night.

At an early hour to-day two of the original towing ships let go their lined and the dock, drawing only eight feat of water and floating like some hege balolon on the water, was slowly towed by the Potomac and another tugboat down the channel towards her berth, which is situated where normally two ships moor (No. 8 black buoys) on the Asian Shore of the harbour. The immense structure, with its four huge chimney stacks and Marconi wireless mast and signal stall, was watched by hundreds of people, residents and others, as it slowly, but by no means majestically, wended its way up the crowded harbour.

By eleven, aided by the steam launches of the American cruiser Tacoma and several small boats belonging to the ships and £anal, her lines were fast to the head and stem buoys, but so unwieldly is the dock that even now (5 p.m.) work is still going on aboard and steam issues from winches and machinery from which lines and hawsers innumerable all lead to mooring posts and buoys.

Yesterday, Sir Vincent Corbett, Financial Adviser, had an interview with Mr. Debonig, the general manager of the Egyptian Salt and Soda Company, and informed him that the Egyptian Government was willing to abstain from the exploitation of their Balines for a period of fourteen years from and beyond the six years to which it is now pledged.

In return for this important concession the Salt and Soda Company has undertaken, at the expiration of the first period of six yean, to reduce the price of salt throughout Egypt to P.T. 180 per ton, and after a farther period of seven years to reduce it to P.T. 150 per ton in Lower Egypt. The precise limits indicated by the term “Lower Egypt” will be decided after discussion between the Egyptian Government and the Salt and Soda Company.

The shareholders of the company ought to be very grateful to the Government for its generous policy in this respect. It is moreover a policy dictated in the interests of the public as the company assures a steady supply of good salt at an even price throughout the whole country. »
The decision of the Government is fora period of twenty veiw from the 1st January, 19°6.
ABOUKIR COMPANY.

It would appear from the dividend announcement by the Abonkir Company, [which was recently published, that continued prosperity has attended the operations of the company during the past year. The net profit is £28,500, or £5,400 more than for the previous twelve months, which, with the sum now brought into the account, makes an available balance of nearly £33.500, as against 25,800 a year ago, when all the arrears of dividend on the Ordinary shares were paid np. The directors, however, prefer to adopt a cautions policy, and limit their recommendation to a 7 percent. distribution for the year on the Ordinary and Deterred shares. This is the same rate as for the previous twelve months (exclusive of the arrears), and it leaves the handsome, sum of £21,700 to be carried forward, as against £5,000 brought into the account.
EGYPTIAN MINE OPERATIONS.

Nile Valley. — The manager cables under date Allagui, 8th April, 1908, giving the result of the March crushing :—“The ten- stamp battery crushed 1 045 tons of 2,000 lbs for a yield of 605 oz., valued at £1.740; average assay value of tailings is 2.30 dwts. The total footage of development work during the month was 10’ ft."

Urn Rub Gold Mines of Egypt. A cablegram gives the following return for March :— “696 tons of ore were crushed, 367 ozs. of bar gold were produced, valued at £1,249. 557 tons of tailings have been stored, of an average assay value of 3 dwta per ton. The mill ran 21 days of 24 hours.’’

div.head: PATRIARCHATE OF ANTIOCH
OPINION OF MGR. PHOTIUS
RUSSIAN INTRGUES IN SYRIA
div.p: From our Correspondent.)

Constantinople, April 10. The Holy Synod of the Greek Patriarchate of Constantinople, at a recent sitting, discussed at length the question relating to the electorate for the Orthodox Patriarchate of Antioch which has been vacant since the death of Mgr. Meletins, the Arabian. In the course of this sitting, a letter was read from Mgr. Photins- the Orthodox

Patriaroh of Alexandria, embo, dying the official opinion of his Beatitude on the matter. In this letter the status of the Patriarchate of Antioch is described as uncanonical, and regret is expressed that no desire is manifest for a solution of the question. Furthermore, his Beatitude recommends the united action of the three Patriarchates, and, accepting the initiative of the (Ecumenical Patriarch, signifies his assent to any action that may lead towards the desired end.
The measures suggested by his Beatitude for restoring order to the See of Antioch are the following :—

Firstly. That the prelates who had been removed return to Damascus, resume their seats on the Holy Synod, and take part, in the election of the new Patriarch in common with all the other regular prelates, of the Church ; and that the others retire, subject to a future decision.
Secondly. That the election be proceeded with according to the statue quo ante.

A long discussion ensued, the (Esumenioal Patriarch declaring himself as sharing the opinion of the Patriarch of Alexandria, while the Metropolitan of Nicomedia opposed it, as interfering with the affairs of an Autocephalous Church. The others members of the Holy Synod, headed by the Metropolitan of Ghano-Hora, Bided with the Patriarch, and on being submitted to the vote it was carried with a majority. It was, however, decided to adjourn the question to a future date, when it would be thoroughly investigated.

This question of the election to the Patriarchate of Antioch has always been a vexed one in Eastern Church politics, and so it is likely to continue until, or unless, either the. position of Greek Orthodoxy is strengthened in Syria, or the principle of self-government for the Autocephalous Churches is better understood and more folly developed. Snob a development, however, would imply independence of the Archiepiscopal Throne of Constantinople, which canonieally rales these several autonomous Patriarchates, and has always maintained the attributes of Head of the Orthodox Greek Church. Unhappily, in the case of Syria, where the Greek position was never strong, Russian intrigue has undermined the influence of the Phanar, and despite the reverses of fortune which that Empire has sustained in the Far East, has nevertheless always managed to fill the voting-urn of the ecolesiastical electorate with its own party votes; and it is well known that the Patriach of Antioch irai aver been a mere poppet of Tsardom.

It is against this spiritual protectorate of Russia in Syria that Joachim III. has taken his stand with charaoteristic energy, but the internal dissensions of the Phanar, the discord of the Holy Synod, and the weakness of the Orthodox Party are calculated to avail bat little when opposed to the stronghold which intrigue has secured for Russia in the Holy Land. Could Jo whim III. rely on stronger supporters than his merchant friends, and had he less influential enemies, he might do much to purge the Orthodox Angean Stables of the foreign cabils and much: nations which cumber it. Alas I for his righteous purposes, his wont opponents are the very clergy whom he rales, and who are ever on the alert to thwart him in his disciplinary measures. His strict notions regarding the Greek Liturgy has lost him the Church of Roumaoia. Let us see how his Holiness will fare in the forthcoming elections for the Episcopal Throne of Antioch.
ALEXANDRIA ARCHAEOLOGICAL SOCIETY.

Yesterday afternoon the second of the series of excursions organised by the Committee of the Alexandria Archaeological Society took place, and a large number of persons met at 4 p.m. at Gabbari Gate, whence they proceeded to Mex to view the latest discoveries of Professor Breccia. The professor gave an account of the history of the necropolis of Alexandria and described the painted tomb that (had recently been discovered. The tomb has been described in our columns and it of considerable archaeological importance} M. Malavel stated that he was ready to undertake the work of restoration, and his decision was heartily applauded.

A visit was next paid to the vast underground necropolis known as the “Batiks of Cleopatra.” Other fine tombs analogous in some respects to those at Korn el Shongafa were explored and the party then proceeded to Pompey’s Pillar to see the three magnificent sphinxes recently found there.
The third excursion will take place on the 26th inst. The party will meet at 5 p.m. at the Eastern Necropolis at Chatby, where some tombs will lie opened.
MILITARY SCHOOL SPORTS

The annual athletic meetin go f the military school, Cairo, will take place on the OBservatory parage-ground. Abbassieh, at 4 p.m. on Thursday, 26th inst. Lady Cromer has kindly consented to give away the prize. A military band will attend.

div.head: FASHIONABLE WEDDING
GORDON BARKER
div.p: The marriage of Mus Gertrude May Barker, daughter of Mr. Henry Barker, Norwegian Consul-General at Alexandria, to Mr. Stanley Innes Gordon, was celebrated at St Mark’s Church, Alexandria, yesterday (Primrose Day). The ceremony was conducted by Rev. Canon Ward, M.A., assisted by Rev. F. B. N. Norman Lee, C.F. The church was crowded with the many distinguished and fashionable members of Cairo and Alexandria society who responded to the invitations. The church presented a most charming effect in its artistic decoration of White Nile lilies and roses intertwined with verdnie. and for this extremely pleasing ‘coup d’ceil” Mrs. Algernon Ward was responsible. The choral part of the ceremony was beautifully carried out by a few chosen friends. At 10.30 the bride, accompanied by her brother, Mr. H. B. Barker, who gave her away, proceeded up the aisle to the exquisite strains of the Wedding March from Lohengrin expressively rendered on the organ by Mr. Stanley Heaton. She was attended by her two winsome bridesmaids. Miss Lang Anderson and Miss Gladys Gordon (sister of the bridegroom); her train was nobly borne by her charming little nephew and niece, Master Basil Ben well Rees and Miss Beryl Alice Barker. The bride looked strikingly beautiful in her dress of white chiffon ninon, richly trimmed with Ducheese lace and lightened op with sprigs of orange blossom, and tulle and white satin ribbon. Her vary handsome veil of Brussel* appliqu was gracefully arranged upon her head over a bunch of orange blossom and fastened with a diamond crescent, the gift of the bridegroom; she wore a “dog” collar of exquisite pearls set with diamonds, the gift of her mother, and carried a magnificent trailing bouquet of white flowers. The bridesmaids wore charming white “chiffon popline” gowns, with belts of primrose coloured silk, and becoming hats of white chiffon adorned aqith primroses; each carried a trailing bouquet of primroses in compliment to the day. Their gifts from the bridegroom were birthday-stone curb chain, gold bracelets. Master Basil Ben- well Rees was attired in a page’s coetnme of white silk with deep collar and cuffs of rich embroidery; he wore a “buttonhole” of primroses fastened with a gold fox-head safety-pin, the gift of the bride. Miss Beryl Alice Barker’s frock was of white chiffon and Irish lace; her bead was crowned with a bewitching Juillet cap of primroses; her present from the bride was a gold merely-thought' inisle Coe brooch. The bridegroom^ was supported by his couain, Mr. Edward Holland, who acted as “best-man,” having coma from Smyrna for the purpose.

After the ceremony was over a reception was held by Mrs. Barker (who wore a beautiful gown of, black sequin lace over grey silk) at her residence in -the Greek quarter. The baskets and bouquets of flowers sent by many kind friends were so numerous and handsome that the house presented the appearance of an immense bower of exquisite blossoms. The reception-rooms wore thronged with guest i all come to wish the bridal pair long life and happiness. A lavish buffet was done full justice to. The wedding cake, which was provided by Messrs. Bolland and Bolland, of Chester, was a great source of interest: it was arranged in three tiers, surmountel by a vase, from which trailed a lovely bouquet and white Batin streamers with welding hells. The bride, in a most becoming costume, of brown mohair trimmed with gold sequins and a toque to match, left amidst a shower of rice and hearty good wishes. The happy couple proceeded to the station en route for Cairo, where they intend spending their honeymoon. They were accompanied to the station by the bridesmaids and a few relations. The presents, which ware on view, were numerous and extremely ; beautiful; a list of them will be given at a later date. Telegrams and well-wished from absent friends were continous throughout the day. M. Pierre Dagnand’s delightful string band played many pleastant selections during the afternoon.

Among those present were: — HE. the Governor of Alexandria, the Sab Governor of Alexandria, Mr. B. B. Gould, I.3.O., H.B.M.’s Consul-General, and Mrs. Gould, M. Girard, French Consul-General, and Mme Girard, Major and the Hon. Mrs. Hopkinson, Rear- Admiral Sir Massie Blomfiald, Mr. and Mrs. Borchgrevink, Mr. and Mrs. Percival Foster, Mr. and Mrs. Stephan Gordon, and many others.

div.head: "FAIRHAVEN."
div.p: The laying of the foundation stone of “Fair- haven,” a house of rest for missionaries in Egypt, took place on Wednesday afternoon, the ceremony, which was of a simple character, be.ng performed by the Right Riv. Bishop Morley, D.D., Archdeacon in Egypt, i (he presence of a small gathering. The procrodings commenced by the singing of the hymn, *T heard the voice of Jeans sty,” after which Bishop Morley delivered a brief address at the conclusion of which he asked for the blessing of God on the good work inaugurated by Miss Van Sommers. Mr. George Swan, of Cairo, described the objects of ‘Ft i: haven” in eloquent terms, and after prayers wire said Bishop

Morley performed the ceremony of laying the foundation stone. Io the cavity under the stone was placed a bottle count lining a parchment which bore the names of the trustees, Miss Van Sommers, Mr. J. M. Cleaver, and Mr. George Swan, with details of the day’s proceedings. The singing of “Abide with me” by all present brought to a close what was a simple but at the same time an Impressive ceremony.

Many of our readers will no doubt be interested to learn the aims of the institution which is shortly to rise close to the Khedivah- Mother’s Palace. These are best described in the founder's (Miss Van Sommers) own words :—

“In going in and out of the homes of missionaries, up and down Egypt, I have sometimes felt a longing desire for soma quiet spot to which I could take a tired mother, or a worker just beginning to break down, and nurse them back to health and strength again. There are about sixty men missionaries, about ninety women, and some twenty children in the country the rest of the children are in the Homeland.

“Amongst these one hundred and seventy people who are living away from their own climate, there are always some who are needing care and a little comfort'; some who, if they fail to have it just then, will straggle on, but will probably in a) fop* months have an illness which might have been prevented.

“And the purpose seemed to be formed of necessity to aeek.to build a house near the sea to become a place of resort for «11 missionaries of Every society in Egypt, who might need home care and comfort, together with a change of air and rest.

“And this is what we want “Fairhaven” to be. We found a rite for it in à breezy spot on the edge of the desert; lopking 'towards the Mediterranean, Where the pato dftert ait will invigorate, and the fresh sea breeze will revive.

“It is near y tiirefrqdarters of 'an acre in extent/and there will be room to build a good house of two stories : a basement for stores and kitchens : aground flour for sitting rooms, and* floor upstairs for bed-rooms. There is no need for a large place. We can begin with a small house, and then, if more rooms are reeded they can be added some day. I should seek to find one or two friends to join men keeping house, and then one of that would be always there to take charge, and be ready to receive oar missionary friends whenever they need to come.

Probably there will not be more than two or three at a time for a grant part of the year, and then, when the hast begins in May, it will bs fall until the end of September. It is possible that in the months when it is not so much wanted by the missionaries in Egypt, there may be an opportunity of taking in friends from England—Home missionaries who need rest and change. I have bought the land in the name of trustees and have asked Mr. J. M. Cleaver and Mr. George Swan to tinder- take the trust together with me, in the desire that it maybe e permanent help and blearing to English, American, and Dutch missionaries in Egypt.

div.head: UNION ASSURANCE SOCIETY
div.p: The following circular has been issued ;—

Dear Sir,—I have the pleasure to inform you that with a view to the extension of their business in Egypt the Directors of the Union Assurance Society have opened a branch office for that country at No. 9 Seaostria Street, Alexandria, and have appointed Mr. Francis Franghia, who formerly had charge of the interests of the society in Asia Minor, as their Branch Manager.

I am happy to able to say that although we shall no longer be able to be represented by our valued and highly esteemed Agents, Messrs. William Getty and Company, we are assured of their continued good will and cooperation. — Yours faithfully,
Joseph Powell, General Manager & Secretary.
Alexandria, April 19,1906.

div.head: TO-DAYS TELEGRAMS
FRISCO PRACTICALLY DESTROYED
SEVERAL TOWNS WRECKED
THOUSDANDS HOMELESS
THE CITY IN FLAMES
div.p: San Francisco, April 19.

According to the latest estimates 1000 persons have been killed and a thousand injured. No ono is allowed to enter the city, which is burning furiou.ly in all quarters. Dynamite explosions for the purpose of checking the flames are adding to the terror of the population. Information to hand is fragmentary owing to the horning of the telegraph and newspaper offices. A moderate estimate of the pecunisry loss places the amount at one hundred million dollars. Two regiments an guarding the property placed in the streets. (Reut-k,
New York, April J9.

General Fanston, commanding at San Francisco, reported yesterday evening that there were about one thousand dead and a hundred thousand homeless. Rations and tents are urgently needed. According to the latest accounts, dense smoke, due to the conflagration which Overspreads this city, is visible for miles out at sea. It looks as if the whole city were doomed to the flames. Many famous buildings, hotels, and theatres have collapsed or been burned down. Chinatown and the Japanese quarter have been destroyed.
The Californian towns of Santa Cruz, Monterey, Gilroy and Hollister have been wrecked and many people killed.
Two hundred people have been killed at Santarosa and tan thousand are homeless.
The shipping at San Franciso is undamaged.
At Leland, Standford University has been considerably damaged.

(Later). General Funston reports that 8an Francisco is practically destroyed : the contflagrations have now become uncontrollable. 200,000 people are homeless : food is very scarce, the provision stores having all been destroyed. The Government are sending immense supplies and cities are vying with each other in affording relief.
The Senate has voted 000,000 dollars. The mortality is practically confined to the tenement dwellings.
SITUATION UNDOUBTEDLY 8ERIOUS.
Durban, April 19.

The Natal Government has resolved to form several powerful columns of irregulars, and to avoid the offensive until an adequate force is ready. The rebels are unlikely to emerge from their fastnesses, and there is therefore no immediate danger, but the situation is undoubtedly serious.

Enlistment for the irregulars is proceeding rapidly. They are to be styled Royston's Stark Horse. An offer of the noted Boer General Cherry Emmett to supply a commando of 250 Vryheid Boers has been accepted.
INVENTOR OF RADIUM KILLED. CRUSHED BY A WAGGON.
Paris, April 19.
M. Curie, the discoverer of radium, slipped in the street and was crashed by a heavy wagon. - (Reuter)
Parts, April 19 J M. Curie, the inventor of radium, has been killed, having been crashed by a wagon.
M- Pierre Curie is known to fame for his researches on radium, carried out in conjunction with his wife. He was born in 1869 and has been a Professor to the Sorbonne Science Faculty since 1000.
FRENCH STRIKE DISTURBANCES.
Lille, April 19.

Strikers have wrecked the mine manager’s house at Lens and repulsed a bayonet charge by a hail of stones. The officials of the ironworks of Denain are besieged ; the troops are powerless : series of affray? are taking place et Lens in which many soldiers 'have wen wounded and two officers dangerously. The labour leader and deputy M, Basly was hooted and stored, (Reuter)

Quiet has been restored. The lieutenant who w»s injured is dead.

div.head: EGYPT'S QUAIL TRADE
div.p: A minor branch of Egypt’s exports but a branch, nevertheless, of considerable profit to the “fellah” is the trade in live quails.
The following table gives the Customs Ratume relating to the shipments during the past five years.

The situation of the quail breeding grounds is a disputed point, though some of the best opinions lean towards Greece and Italy. At any rate, the birds come across the Mediterranean at the beginning of the autumn on their way to the Sudan, and return at the commencement of spring.

The main export season is the autumn one, which lasts from about the 10th of September to the end of October. The birds, exhausted after their long journey, fly low on approaching the land, with the result that they are caught in vast quantities by means of large nets held in a vertical position by long poles.

From the beginning of March until the end of May the quails return from the Sudan, and chiefly caputured in Upper Egypt, very fews being caught in the Lower PRovinces. In September the Arabs bring the birds into Alexandria, where they are sold to the merchants, it being only necessary for dealers to ' employ baying agents in the Damietta and Rosetta districts. In March, however, the quails are collected from the natives through agents, and then sent by tail to Alexandria.

For export purposes, the birds are packed in orates holding (0Q each, five or six orates 1 fastened together by means of timber forming 1 a ' handle,” The quails are shipped on deck— accompanied by one or two Arabs to attend to I them— and usually travel by long sea to ] London, Manchester, or Liverpool, the freight running from 10/- to 15/- a “bundle.”

Both seasons are bad ones from a shipping point of view, and it is, therefore, scarcely surprising to learn that the mortality Is generally from 10 % to 15 %, mainly due to exposure. We understand the mortality from starvation is exceedingly small, and that the birds do not suffer from overcrowding. The marine insurance policies only cover the total loss of a whole '•bundle” (including crates), and we gather that claims in this connection are very rare. In fact, a man who was engaged in the j trade for 95 years told the writer that he had never known an instance of a whole "bundle" being lost at sea.

Some years ago, the trade was all done overland viA Marseilles, the death rate being as low as 3 % to 6 %. Stress of competition, plus certain regulations put into force by the French Government, compelled the merchants to adopt the long sea journey, which, of course, is punch cheaper than the former route.

With regard to selling prices, contracts are usually made by the merchants for the while of a season at from 6d to 7d a bird delivered alive to London. Five or six years ago, the figures ran about 9d and 101.

At the beginning of the March season, merchants p*y the "fellah” P.T. 2 to P.T. 9.5 (5d to 6d) a bird, dropping from these figures to about P.T. I (2jd) in April. Birds being more plentiful, and the demand slacker,1 in September, prices naturally rale lower, Hie native obtaining P.T. 1 to P.T. 1.5 (2ld to 3)d) a quail at the opening of the season.

It will be observed from the statistics at the commencement of this article that since 1902 the number of quails shipped abroad hast gradually decreased year by year. This shrinkage is chiefly due to Government restrictions in connection with the capture of the birds, though, during the last year or two, a further season is to be found in the action of the exporters in lowering the prices paid to the fellah. The natives in many instances considered that it was not worth their while to obtain the quails for the merchants, and exports suffered accordingly.

Daring the past two years, practically the whole of the export trade in quails was done through an Egyptian Syndicate of four shippers, the buyers in London being an Italian fi>m and an English combination of two houses. The pooling arrangements came to an end last Christmas, when two of the shipping firms dropped out of the business. There- maining firms are now working together and endeavouring to do their own telling in London, thus cutting the English merchants out of the trade.

It is at present impossible to say whether the scheme will succeed, though prompt measures have been taken to defeat it. A partner in one of the English firms has just been over to Egypt with the object of making arrangements for scouring a supply of birds, and we believe the visit has been more or less successful, notwithstanding that the monopoly established by the Egyptian syndicate is a very strong one. (Journal oj British Chamber of Commerce.)

div.head: THE NILE ROUTE TO THE CONGO
div.p: The Brassais correspondent of the "Globe” writes :—

It is stated that the refusai of the Bgyptian anthorities to allow the passage of convoya with goods and materials for the Frae State to the Congo by way of the Nile has been with drawn. This refusal was caused, according to the ofiicial statements, by the presence of troops of the Free State on the border territories, which troops the Congo Government dedined, or negleoted, to withdraw.

The Egyptian Government, on its side, declined to allow of the carriage of artioles which might be destined for these troops, through its terri tories. The Free State has been in the habit of revictualling its agents in the Tanganyka district by the Nile route, and also of sending by that route ail material destined for the border parts of its territories, and it was said that the refusai of the Egyptien Government to allow the Congo convoya to pass by the Nile in future was the cause of the ravivai of the carrier servira, which in former days, when the natives were pressed into the service to many ail the heavy loads of the State on their banks, weighed so heavily on the blacks as to cause immense mortality among them. It is nowatat- ed that there hâve been reshipped for Alex- an tria a large number of consigmngnts, which belong to the Congo Government, and which were returned from there some months and to Antwerp, on the refusal of the Egyptien authorities to allow them to be canied into the Congo State by way of the Nile. Among the goods which form the reshipped consignaient, there ara several automobiles. It is believed in Belgium that the reopening r f the Nile route to the Congo is an indication of a botter on- deratanding come to between England and the Congo.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET
div.p: KEARLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT. Liverpool, April 11. A good business has been done in Egyptian Cotton on the SPot this week, and quotations fo Brown are raised. Upper 2/3 per lb. In Futures an active business has been done, and the latest values are :- Apr. 10.12 July 10.10 Oct. 9.20 May 10.14 Aug. 10.2 Nov. 8.58 June 10.12 Sept. 9.55 Dec. 8.46 Jan. 8.40 American Futures.- The market this week has been fairly active and prices have had an advacning tendency, to-day's values being generally 9 points higher for the New Crop positions, than last THursday. The improvement is cheifly due to the continued large takings of spinners, to mixed weather conditions (although latterly showing some improvements.) and to manipulation, principally initiated by operators in the American markets of outside speculation there is still remarkablylittle, and the good trade conditions remain backbone of the market. Apparently there is very little apprehension that the demand of the operatives for an increase in their wasges will lead to a conflict between them and the employers. Un-doubtedly the position requires careful watching; any fear of a strike might seriously affect prices.
